The military forces which Cassius had already at his command were considerably strengthened by extensive levies in Galatia and Phrygia, and thus the exiled kings were restored to their dominions by force of arms. Not contented with having recovered his throne, Nicomedes, pressed by the demands for money made -by the Roman generals, then made an inroad into the >territory of Mithridates, pillaging it as far as the town of Amastris, without meeting any enemy. For Mithridates, though in possession of an army ready for action, had intentionally retreated‚ in order to have many good reasons for a war¹¹.

4. The cunning king knew well who had really occasioned this raid ; but he sent a Greek agent, named Pelopidas, to the Roman envoys, to obtain satisfaction from them. As might have been expected, their answer was one of hesitation and refusal. The king thereupon, regardjng the rejection of his claim for satisfaction as an open breach, sent his son Ariarathes with a large army into Cappadocia, to seize the throne. In a short time Ariobarzanes was driven out, and Ariarathes master of the land. Its occupation was the signal for the outbreak of the war with Rome
